channel.title: Peter's stats stuff
channel.description: I write about applications of data and analytical techniques like statistical modelling and simulation to real-world situations. I show how to access and use data, and provide examples of analytical products and the code that produced them.

item.title: Estimating Gini coefficient when we only have mean income by decile
item.description: Calculating the Gini coefficient for inequality directly of mean income by decile produces a slightly biased downwards estimate. I correct for this and demonstrate on the World Panel Income Distribution data.

item.title: Sampling distribution of weighted Gini coefficient
item.description: I play around with the sampling distribution of Gini coefficients calculated with weighted data; and verify that the Gini calculation method in a recent Stats NZ working paper is the one in the acid R package.

item.title: Inter-country inequality and the World Development Indicators
item.description: I play around with population-weighted income inequality of countries with data from the World Development Indicators, re-creating (with some amendments) some graphics from Branko Milanovic's recent book "Global Inequality".

item.title: Who turned out to vote in the 2014 New Zealand general election?
item.description: I explore the demographic characteristics of who voted (and who didn't), out of people on the electoral roll, in the 2014 New Zealand general election. I use multiple imputation and a generalized linear model with a quasibinomial response. The people who vote tend to have characteristics associated with doing ok out of society (owning a home, having a partner, university qualifications, etc).

item.title: Improving state-space modelling of the Australian 2007 federal election
item.description: I revisit the state space model of Labor party vote leading up to the 2007 Australian election; and a re-think about total survey error in the context of polling data leads to a more stable, less wiggly underlying state of voting intention. Also, vectorization in Stan leads to much faster estimation.

item.title: Family violence and economic deprivation in New Zealand
item.description: I look at the interaction between deprivation, being MƒÅori, and family violence - combining data from the New Zealand census, the New Zealand index of deprivation, and the Family Violence Death Review Committee.

item.title: State-space modelling of the Australian 2007 federal election
item.description: As part of familiarising myself with the Stan probabilistic programming language, I replicate Simon Jackman's state space modelling with house effects of the 2007 Australian federal election.

item.title: Stats NZ encouraging active sharing for microdata access projects
item.description: Excited that New Zealand's Government Statistician is promoting reproducibility and open access to code, tabular outputs and research products from research with confidentialised microdata.

item.title: Global choropleth maps of military expenditure
item.description: For choropleth maps showing the whole world, we don't need to stick to static maps with Mercator projections. I like rotating globes, and interactive slippery maps with tooltips.

item.title: Sankey charts for swinging voters
item.description: Sankey charts based on individual level survey data are a good way of showing change from election to election. I demonstrate this, via some complications with survey-reweighting and missing data, with the New Zealand Election Study for the 2014 and 2011 elections.
